prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not going to my best friends wedding.
So my best friend (lets call her G) has decided to have her wedding, that's awesome and I'm happy she found the one. 

The issue is G never sent out save the dates, meaning last week we got the actual wedding invitations for a wedding that is happening in 1 month.  

It will be at her grandmother's Ranch and it seems like a pretty nice wedding. 

here is where the issue started. 

a few months ago me and 3 friends decided to plan a trip to Australia to backpack/sightsee for 2 weeks, the trip starts 2 days before the wedding so we can't go. G knew about the trip as we invited her but I'm geussing she forgot. 
she is mad at all of us for not just cancelling the trip and being at her wedding. 

all of us are not super rich so this would be a huge loss if we cancelled the trip. (so we are not) 

I also want to add that she invited 50 people, I asked. and only 20 can make it as she gave 1 month notice. 

she is flipping her shit and acting like we should drop everything for her. 

AITA for not just cancelling my 2 week trip to go to her wedding? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for not attending their best friend's wedding. The friend didn't send a save-the-date, just the actual invite a month before the wedding. The author and three friends had planned a trip to Australia that starts two days before the wedding, and they can't cancel because it's a huge financial loss. The friend is upset and expects them to drop everything, even though only 20 out of 50 invited guests can make it.

First, I need to consider the friend's actions. Not sending a save-the-date is a big oversight, especially for a close friend's wedding. Usually, save-the-dates are sent out several months in advance so guests have time to plan. The author mentions the trip was planned months ago, and they had invited the friend, who apparently forgot or didn't remember. That's a key point. The friend's poor planning led to this conflict.

Then, the financial aspect. The author and friends aren't wealthy, so canceling the trip would be a huge loss. That's a valid reason not to go back on their plans. The trip was planned ahead of time, and the friend's late notice made it impossible to adjust. The friend is upset, but expecting others to sacrifice financially for a last-minute invite isn't fair.

Also, the fact that only 20 out of 50 guests can attend shows that the short notice affected many people. The author isn't the only one who can't make it, so the friend's reaction might be unreasonable. The author isn't being inconsiderate; they tried to plan ahead and are facing consequences beyond their control.

On the other hand, maybe the author should have checked in with the friend about the wedding date earlier. But since the friend didn't send a save-the-date, that's on her. The author isn't at fault here. The situation is more about the friend's poor communication and planning. So, the answer is B—the author isn't in the wrong.
